author: Jonathan Walker
title: Article 50: Joy and fear at Westminster as MPs remain divided over Brexit
text:
EU and Union Flags fly outside Parliament (Photo: AP Photo/Kirsty Wigglesworth) Share Get daily     
Brexit began this week, but MPs are still deeply divided about it. 
Theresa May spoke in the House of Commons on Wednesday to confirm that her letter triggering Article 50 of the Treaty on European Union had been delivered. 
She said: “In accordance with the wishes of the British people, the United Kingdom is leaving the European Union.” 
And the announcement was greeted with joy by Brexiteers. 
Some of them have been fighting to take the UK out of the European Union for years - or decades. 
And they’ve frequently been ridiculed and attacked as bigots, racists or worse. 
Conservative MP Peter Bone is one. Responding to the Prime Minister’s announcement, he told her: “Some Government Members and some Opposition Members have worked throughout their political career to extract the United Kingdom from the European superstate. Prime Minister Theresa May during an interview with Andrew Neil on BBC1 
“Sometimes we were isolated, sometimes we were ignored, and sometimes we were insulted, but thanks to the British people, today we are leaving the European Union.” 
But other MPs are downcast, and worry that regions like the North East, where exports are particularly important for jobs, are going to suffer. 
They include Catherine McKinnell , MP for Newcastle upon Tyne North and one of the Labour MPs who voted against the Government’s Brexit Bill in February. 
She responded to Mrs May’s announcement by saying: “Leaving the EU will have a significant impact on the North East and our economy for decades to come – and yet we still have no idea how, or even if, the Government intends to properly engage with the region to ensure our interests are secured as part of these negotiations. 
“The Government has promised that the trade deal they want to reach will deliver ‘the exact same benefits’ we currently enjoy, and this is critical for the North East given that almost 60% of our exports currently go to the EU.” Britain's permanent representative to the European Union Tim Barrow, left, hand delivers British Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit letter in notice of the UK's intention to leave the bloc under Article 50 of the EU's Lisbon Treaty to EU Council President Donald Tusk, in Brussels, Belgium, Wednesday, March 29, 2017 (Photo: REUTERS POOL) 
Like many opposition MPs, Mrs McKinnell was unhappy that the Prime Minister’s letter to European Council President Donald Tusk said the UK wants “to agree a deep and special partnership between the UK and the EU, taking in both economic and security cooperation”. 
Some MPs and commentators think this amounts to a threat to stop working with the EU on security issues unless it offers the UK a good trade deal. 
Mrs May, of course, insists that the UK is going to get a trade agreement, so this isn’t really an issue. Read More Will Newcastle United's recruitment be affected by Brexit? New calls for football to be 'exempt' 
The Article 50 announcement wasn’t the only important bit of Brexit business at Westminster.
